content:
Let F:Top→SetF : \mathcal{T}^{op} \to \mathsf{Set}F:Top→Set be a presheaf on a topological space (X,T)(X,\mathcal{T})(X,T) that is flasque, meaning whenever i:U↪Vi : U \hookrightarrow Vi:U↪V the restriction map Fi:FV→FUF i : FV \to FUFi:FV→FU is surjective.

Then is the following true: for all U,VU,VU,V and x∈FU,y∈FVx \in F U, y \in F Vx∈FU,y∈FV such that x∣U∩V=y∣U∩V{x \mid_{U \cap V}} = {y \mid_{U \cap V}}x∣U∩V​=y∣U∩V​, there exists z∈F(U∪V)z \in F(U \cup V)z∈F(U∪V) with z∣U=x{z \mid_U = x}z∣U​=x and z∣V=y{z \mid_V = y}z∣V​=y?

If not, is there a simple counterexample?

Ok, I think this may be a counterexample...

Let X={a,b,c}X = \{a,b,c\}X={a,b,c} be a space generated by the two open sets U={a,b},V={b,c}U = \{a,b\}, V = \{b, c\}U={a,b},V={b,c}, so T={∅,{b},U,V,X}\mathcal{T} = \{ \emptyset, \{b\}, U, V, X \}T={∅,{b},U,V,X}.

Let FFF be defined as follows:
F∅={()} F \emptyset = \{ () \}F∅={()},
F{b}:={(b0)} F \{b\} := \{ (b_0) \}F{b}:={(b0​)},
FU:={(a0,b0),(a1,b0)}F U := \{ (a_0, b_0) , (a_1, b_0) \}FU:={(a0​,b0​),(a1​,b0​)},
FV:={(b0,c0),(b0,c1)}F V := \{ (b_0, c_0), (b_0, c_1) \}FV:={(b0​,c0​),(b0​,c1​)},
FX:={(a0,b0,c1),(a1,b0,c0)} FX:= \{ (a_0, b_0, c_1) , (a_1, b_0, c_0) \}FX:={(a0​,b0​,c1​),(a1​,b0​,c0​)}.

And the action of FFF on inclusions is by restriction of tuples.

Then take x=(a0,b0)x = (a_0, b_0)x=(a0​,b0​), y=(b0,c0)y = (b_0, c_0)y=(b0​,c0​). Then these agree on restriction to {b}\{b\}{b}, but we cannot find z∈F(U∪V)z \in F(U \cup V)z∈F(U∪V) restricting to both xxx and yyy. Is this correct?

I would even go so far as to say FU={a0,a1}×{b0}FU = \{a_0,a_1\} \times \{b_0\}FU={a0​,a1​}×{b0​}, FV={b0}×{c0,c1}FV = \{b_0\}\times \{c_0,c_1\}FV={b0​}×{c0​,c1​}, and FX={b0}×{(a0,c1),(a1,c0)}.FX = \{b_0\}\times \{(a_0,c_1),(a_1,c_0)\}.FX={b0​}×{(a0​,c1​),(a1​,c0​)}.
